data.title: Git - terse error message when doing a git commit
data.body:
Please see the screenshot below. The error message only consists of a file name.  

Minimally add a generic message that a git operation failed.

What is strange about the error message is that the file that is causing the trouble is .vscode/launch.json, but the .vscode folder is listed in the .gitignore file.

data.title: Implement join editors command
data.body:
Fixes #20279

This command joins the editor group with the previous group (except for the first group which joins with the next group).

The order of editors in the joining group is preserved when joining with the target group. 

If an editor is opened in both the joining and target group, only one will be kept, in the same position as in the joining group.

![vscode-join-editors](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/19281538/23820407/ab9b9302-0652-11e7-9492-c9767ea637e4.gif)

data.title: Make update notifications less intrusive
data.body:
It seems like VS Code has some kind of update each time I run it, which is great. However, the big notifications break my workflow. I would love it if the notifications could get out of my way.

- For me the notification has no use. I always click the button 'Later' and the update gets installed silently when I close/reopen at some time. It is a text editor, not a banking app that needs the latest security patch.

- The notification is rather big, so (for me) hard to ignore. Even if I could resist it I am forced to do it because it covers the tabs in the editor.

- If there are release notes, then I want to read those when it suits me. I don't want to interrupt something I'm working on to check the release notes and then figure out what I was supposed to be doing.

What I would like is there to be some kind of small unobtrusive notification (like the flag in regular Visual Studio) that would tell me that there is an update. It could also link to the release notes (after an update) so that I can leave it flagged until I have time to check out the new features. Or just have an option to turn off all notifications related to updates, and always install them silently.

data.title: Feature Request - Add "Copy Relative Path" to Explorer
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.10
- OS Version: Windows 10

Adding the correct relative path for import statements takes time. For example, if you have a lot of files in your project it takes time to determine the correct path i.e.
`import { Link } from '/data-structures/sanitised-data/link';`
`import { Link } from './data-structures/sanitised-data/link';`
`import { Link } from '../data-structures/sanitised-data/link';`
`import { Link } from '../../data-structures/sanitised-data/link';`
 It would be really useful if when you right click on a file in the VS Code explorer there was the option to `copy relative path` next to `Copy Path` and `Copy`. Where the relative path is compared to the active window you have open at the time so you can just copy the import statement in straight away.

data.title: Selecting text using column select then shifting with ALT+ARROW produces different results based on direction of selection
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

This is likely related to issue #22380. Box selecting from top-to-bottom then shifting with ALT+UP/DOWN produces a different line order than if the box select was performed from bottom-to-top.

- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: Windows 10 x64

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open a new file and paste in the following contents (note that there is no trailing whitespace):

```javascript
var a = 'apple crumble';
var b = 'bun'; 
var c = 'chocolate cake';
var d = 'doughnuts';
var e = 'egg';
```

2. Box select from the `b` in `bun` to the `g` in `doughnuts`
3. Release all keys then press ALT+DOWN

Resulting line order: a, c, b, d, e

4. Return the file to the original state
5. Box select from the `g` in `doughnuts` to the `b` in `bun` (reversed direction of selection to the above test)
6. Release all keys then press ALT+DOWN

Resulting line order: a, c, b, e, d

data.title: Only show "The internet connection appears to be offline" message when relevant
data.body:
When using VS Code while not connected to the internet (eg. while traveling), the message stating `The internet connection appears to be offline` quickly becomes an annoyance.

This message ought to only appear when the user _actively_ performs an action which requires an internet connection, for example searching the extension marketplace. Alternatively, it could be replaced with a small icon in the status bar that's much more subtle.

- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: macOS 10.12.3

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Disconnect from the internet
2. Launch VS Code

data.title: Selecting text using column select then moving lines up/down with ALT+arrow inconsistently affects lines
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: Windows 10 x64

When selecting text using columns (either CTRL+SHIFT+ALT+ARROW or SHIFT+ALT+MOUSE1), moving the selected text using ALT+UP/DOWN will always shift the line of the initial cursor position. Shifting the other selected lines appears to depend on whether the selected column exists on the line above.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open a new file and paste in the following contents (note that there is no trailing whitespace):

```javascript
var a = 'apple crumble';
var b = 'bun'; 
var c = 'chocolate cake';
var d = 'doughnuts';
var e = 'egg';
```

2. Box select from the `a` in `apple crumble` to one of the `o`s in `chocolate cake`
3. Release all keys then press ALT+DOWN.

Expected result: All 3 selected lines move. Columns are still selected
Line order: d, a, b, c, e

Actual result: Only first line moves. Only first line has column selected
Line order: b, a, c, d, e

4. Return the file to the original order
5. Box select from the `r` in `apple crumble` to the `s` in `doughnuts`
6. Release all keys then press ALT+DOWN

Expected result: All 3 lines with selected text move. Columns are still selected
Line order: b, a, e, c, d

Actual result: Only first and third lines are moved. Only columns from these 2 lines are selected
Line order: b, a, d, c, e

data.title: Debugger setup tuning for using VS Code with the mern.io starter kit
data.body:
// CC @chrisdias 

http://mern.io/ defines a starter kit for MERN. I was looking with @weinand into the best VS Code debugger setup.

The idea is to use an NPM launch configuration so that the vscode independent launching details can be defined inside the `package.son` and do not have to be defined inside the vscode specific launch configuration.

I've added the following script to the starter kit's `package.json` in the `scripts` section:

```json
"start:debug": "cross-env BABEL_DISABLE_CACHE=1 NODE_ENV=development nodemon --nolazy --inspect=5858 index.js",
```

With the following launch configuration we could launch and debug the target from VS Code. 

The script sets `restart` to true since the starterkit is using nodemon and we want to reattach when nodemon restarts the target program.

```json
        {
            "name": "Launch via NPM",
            "type": "node",
            "request": "launch",
            "protocol": "inspector",
            "cwd": "${workspaceRoot}",
            "runtimeExecutable": "npm",
            "windows": {
                "runtimeExecutable": "npm.cmd"
            },
            "runtimeArgs": [
                "run-script",
                "start:debug"
            ],
            "timeout": 20000,
            "restart": true,
            "port": 5858
        }
```

We've ran into the following glitches:
- using the inspector protocol worked but we did not see all the console output (e.g. the webpack built time) in the DebugConsole.
- when using the `legacy` protocol and the `--debug` option you get a timeout error.
- with the working setup above you need to use the task manager to kill the target program. We tried to configure the launch configuration to use the internal terminal so that we can kill the target from the terminal. When using the internal terminal then the launching failed.

data.title: Tasks echoCommand does not show command in Terminal
data.body:
When using `echoCommand` in tasks.json, the command isn't echoed in the Integrated Terminal.

![harmlessunhappyfeline](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/463564/23792014/1f6e3312-053a-11e7-8799-ab677c442a94.gif)


- VSCode Version: 1.10.2 (1.10.2)
- OS Version: MacOS 10.12.3 (16D32)
- Tasks Version: 2.0.0

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Run Task "echoTest" with `echoCommand`.
```
      {
            "taskName": "echoTest",
            "command": "echo",
            "isShellCommand": true,
            "args": ["Hello World"],
            "showOutput": "always",
            "echoCommand": true
        }
```
2. Observe that output to Integrated Terminal does not prepend the underlying command of Task "echoTest" per [documentation](https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/editor/tasks#_echocommand).

data.title: How to use "oneOf" extension configuration?
Add environment setup support for tasks configuration
data.body:
Im using the tasks.json file to configure my grunt Tasks. Some of them expectect that a given environment variable is set, because they normally are executed with Jenkins where the used plugins for the job execution sets some environment variables I evaluate within the grunt tasks.

It would be awesome if it's possible to pass an array of environment variables, like it's possible with the command args, for example:

```
{
            "taskName": "myCustomGruntTask",
            "identifier": "myCustomGruntTask",
            "args": [""],

            // Set some environment variables here
            "env": [
                     { "PATH": "$PATH;Some value ..." },
                     { "BRANCH_NAME": "testBranch" },
                     .
                     .
                     .
             ]

            "isBuildCommand": true,
            "isWatching": false,
            "problemMatcher": [
                "$lessCompile",
                "$tsc", 
                "$jshint"
            ]
}
```

data.title: Support for live preview and/or "open in browser" shortcut and Format support for PHP
data.body:

Whether it is PHP, HTML or something else there's no all around extension that makes this work flawlessly. Additional you could make a live preview for these file types as well (maybe not for PHP idk). Windows already have a nice way to add the windows to the sides for multitasking, with live preview it would work great!

Also PHP format in HTML files and HTML format in PHP files would be greatly appreciated too!

data.title: Tasks lint and intellisense have conflicting suggestions

milestone.title: On Deck
milestone.description:
The Issues assigned to the **On Deck** milestone under consideration for the upcoming milestones.
Our goal is to always have less than 100 Issues on deck.

data.body:
When using the ["Hello World" Tasks example](https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/editor/tasks#_hello-world), there's a linter for tasks.json. If I resolve the issue, I incur Intellisense's wrath with a red squiggle.

![tasks syntax error](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/463564/23790006/238ac544-0532-11e7-8dd1-16d4ed71b770.png)


![escape with tooltip](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/463564/23790010/25993d84-0532-11e7-90a1-0ca13aa0986f.png)


- VSCode Version: 1.10.2 (1.10.2)
- OS Version: MacOS 10.12.3 (16D32)
- Tasks Version: 2.0.0


Steps to Reproduce:

1. Add "Hello World" to tasks.json, and observe syntax suggestion in Output.
```
        {
            "taskName": "echoTest",
            "command": "echo",
            "isShellCommand": true,
            "args": ["Hello World"],
            "showOutput": "always",
            "echoCommand": true
        }
```

2. Escape "Hello World" spaces, and observe Intellisense error, and tool tip.

data.title: macOS: BundleIdentifier present on my .zshrc file
data.body:
- VSCode Version:  Code Version 1.10.2
- OS Version: macOS 10.12.3

---

I have an alias `morning` on my *.zshrc* file that opens automatically my apps, folders and files on the morning when I am at work.
In this alias, I have this simple function:

``` shell
echo "Opening $# apps..."
for appBundleIdentifier in "$@"
do
  $(open -b $appBundleIdentifier)
done
```

Where `appBundleIdentifier` holds things like `com.apple.mail`, `com.fournova.Tower2`, but also `com.microsoft.VSCode`, which is the Bundle Identifier of Microsoft VS Code.
When I open up VSCode, I have the following message:

> Code needs to change the 'code' shell command. Would you like to do this now ?

then

> Please remove the alias referencing 'com.microsoft.VSCode' in '/MyUser/.zshrc' (line xxx) and retry this action.

then 

> Please remove the 'code' alias from '/MyUser/.zshrc' before continuing.

The thing is I don't have any `code` alias present there. I guess it takes the `com.microsoft.VSCode` as the code alias and thinks it would break the code shell command (which works perfectly btw).

It would be better to dismiss this message and/or disable the check of `code` in the shell ressource file in the VSCode settings.

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Put the VSCode Bundle Identifier on your .bashrc (or .zshrc or any other shell ressource), for example: `echo 'com.microsoft.VSCode'`. Note that it won't work if you put it in comments.
2. Open up VSCode.

data.title: Keyboard combination Alt + arrows in the editor

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.10.2 (8076a19fdcab7e1fc1707952d652f0bb6c6db331, 2017-03-08T14:02:52.799Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14393
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|plantuml|jebbs|1.2.5|
|cpptools|ms-vscode|0.10.2|
|debugger-for-chrome|msjsdiag|2.6.0|
|language-vscode-javascript-angular2|nwallace|0.0.11|
|language-plantuml|qhoekman|0.0.3|
|nativescript|Telerik|0.6.1|;

---

Old schoold people like me, still want the numlock key disabled. This means that "ALT + arrows" (and using the arrows on the numpad of a desktop keyboard) results in inserting an ascii code instead in addition to the keyboard shortcut defined in VSCode.


Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open the editor with some text separated by newlines
2. ALT + Up arrow and ALT + Down arrow move the lines up and down
3. Now turn off the numlock on the keyboard
4. repeat the step at point (2):
   ALT + Up Arrow (on the numpad) lead to inserting the character ◘
   ALT + Down Arrow (on the numpad) lead to inserting the character ☻

I expect the behavior is consistent with Visual Studio where ascii characted are never injected on these keyboard combinations.

Thanks
